Award.AwardTitle: California LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities." The composition of the STEM workforce in the United States, particularly workers with advanced degrees, does not reflect the demographics of the general population. By 2020, more than half of the children under the age of 5 will be part of an underrepresented racial/ethnic group. The goal of the California LSAMP (CAMP) Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) activity at the University of California, Davis (UC Davis) is to increase the quality and diversity of students successfully completing STEM doctoral degree programs and increase the diversity of graduates entering the STEM workforce with the highest level of education.

UC Davis will host the 2016-2018 cohort of the CAMP BD, which will provide fellowship support to 12 underrepresented STEM Ph.D. students. The BD activity at UC Davis is developed based on evidence-based practices and builds on previous successes of other partner institutions in the CAMP alliance. BD Fellows will benefit from state-of-the-art research facilities and a connective network of their peers, post-docs, and faculty, who will be instrumental to their success along the degree pathway. UC Davis' BD will offer professional development and rigorous training in specific STEM disciplines through interactive training and activities that promote networking and leadership in the scientific and engineering communities. In addition, strong community-building activities and events that bring the family into the support network will be pursued. The findings, lessons learned, and impact of the UC Davis BD will be disseminated through social networks, publications, presentations at national meetings, and data sharing processes with NSF-affiliated initiatives and diversity consortiums. UC Davis will implement a rigorous evaluation and longitudinal study of CAMP BD programs, which would result in improved understanding about the effectiveness of programs that seek to increase the diversity and inclusiveness of doctoral-level training in the STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW: The goal of the California LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) program is to prepare students from historically underrepresented groups to persist and complete science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) doctoral degree programs. To this end, UC Davis provided fellowship support to 12 underrepresented minority (URM) STEM Ph.D. students. The program at UC Davis provided the students with the necessary academic and research skills that reduced barriers to successfully completing their STEM doctoral degrees and transition into the professoriate and STEM workforce. Supporting LSAMP students exclusively, the UC Davis BD program offered students access to professional development workshops as well as a connective network of their peers, post-docs, and faculty. Additionally, to reduce financial barriers to pursuing doctoral education, UC Davis BD fellows received stipends for the first two years and the assurance of cost-of-education funds from the academic departments and/or external fellowship funding for the duration of the doctoral program. Building on the previous successes from the other members of the California LSAMP alliance, which to date have supported 93 BD URM graduate students STEM disciplines, the program had distinct successes in establishing a framework on which to develop long-term institutional student supports and interventions aimed at enhancing student success. This was demonstrated by institutional financial support for developing pilot programs based on the BD model and the submission of a grant proposal to provide continuous support for this model of student support.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The proposed BD program at UC Davis provided an opportunity to enrich the body of knowledge about the recruitment, education, graduation and job placement of underrepresented populations in STEM doctoral programs.  Professional development and rigorous training in specific STEM disciplines was accomplished through faculty mentoring, interactive training, and activities that promoted networking and leadership in the scientific and engineering communities. The program’s nurturing and supportive environment ensured timely completion of the critical milestones in the doctoral training process. In order to establish best practices for the recruitment and retention of graduate student researchers and build upon lessons learned from other LSAMP BD host sites, we will employed a rigorous evaluation program and a longitudinal study of the effectiveness of BD programs at the University of California alliance members. This enabled the evidence-based understanding about the effectiveness of programs that seek to increase the diversity and inclusiveness of doctoral level training in the STEM fields that was necessary to develop successive grant proposals. With continued support from Graduate Studies, we anticipate fellows will have a successful transition to competitive careers in academia and industry regionally, nationally, and globally.

BROADER IMPACT: The goal of the BD program at UC Davis was to increase the quality and quantity of students successfully completing STEM doctoral degree programs and increase the number of graduates entering the STEM professions with the highest level of education. The program also sought to strengthen the linkages between existing LSAMP undergraduate programs and UC Davis’s STEM graduate programs with the goal of creating a permanent boost in the pipeline leading to STEM graduate study at UC Davis. Long term, the BD cohort is expected to affect not only the perceptions of the next generation of URM STEM students, for whom they will serve as role models, but ultimately expand participation in the nation’s scientific and engineering workforce. Our findings, lessons learned, and impact of our activities have been and will continue to be disseminated through social networks, publications, presentations at national meetings, and data sharing processes with NSF-affiliated initiatives and diversity consortia. They will have a vital and transformative impact far beyond minority education, STEM disciplines, and the host campus. The evaluation of current practices will help inform programmatic design strategies for increased inclusiveness of underrepresented populations in STEM education.
